extracted_text: budget responsibility bill as brought from the commons contents announcement of fiscally significant measures extent, commencement and short title hl bill as brought from the commons a b i l l to impose duties on the treasury and the office for budget responsibility in respect of the announcement of fiscally significant measures. b e it enacted by the king s most excellent majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons, in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows announcement of fiscally significant measures part of the budget responsibility and national audit act is amended as follows. in section , in subsection after duties imposed insert on the office ; at the end insert and section a. after section insert a announcement of fiscally significant measures if a minister of the crown is proposing to make a fiscal announcement to the house of commons in respect of a measure which is fiscally significant, or two or more measures where any combination of the measures is fiscally significant, the treasury must, before the announcement, request the office to prepare a section report that takes account of the measure or measures. if, in the case of a measure in respect of which a request was required to be made in accordance with subsection and in respect of which no such request has been made, the office is of the opinion that the measure is fiscally significant, the office must as soon as is reasonably practicable notify the treasury committee of the house of commons of its opinion, and hl bill budget responsibility bill prepare a report that includes a costing for the measure report . a measure or combination of measures is fiscally significant if the measure, or combination of measures, has a costing for a specified period that exceeds a specified percentage of the gross domestic product for a specified period. specified means specified in, or determined in accordance with, the charter for budget responsibility. subsections and do not apply in respect of a measure which is intended to have effect for a temporary period only, and is in response to an emergency. the charter may make provision for the purpose of supplementing this section . if the treasury proposes to modify the charter so as to include provision by virtue of this section, a draft of the proposed provision must be published at least days before the modified charter is laid before parliament under section . in this section fiscal announcement means an announcement in respect of any matter mentioned in section ; minister of the crown has the same meaning as in the ministers of the crown act ; request means a request made in accordance with the charter ; section report means a report under section which contains forecasts and an assessment under subsection of that section. it does not matter for the purposes of this section whether or not two or more measures are, or are proposed to be, announced at the same time or at different times. paragraph of schedule applies in respect of the reference in this section to the treasury committee of the house of commons as it applies in respect of references to that committee in schedule . extent, commencement and short title this act extends to england and wales, scotland and northern ireland. section comes into force on such day as the treasury may by regulations made by statutory instrument appoint. different days may be appointed for different purposes. budget responsibility bill this act may be cited as the budget responsibility act . budget responsibility bill

financial assistance to ukraine bill as brought from the commons contents provision of loans or other financial assistance to ukraine short title hl bill as brought from the commons a b i l l to make provision for loans or other financial assistance to be provided to, or for the benefit of, the government of ukraine. b e it enacted by the king s most excellent majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons, in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows provision of loans or other financial assistance to ukraine there may be paid out of money provided by parliament any sums required by the treasury or secretary of state for the purpose of providing loans or other financial assistance to, or for the benefit of, the government of ukraine as a result of the arrangements described as the extraordinary revenue acceleration loans for ukraine announced on june at the g summit in apulia in italy, or any subsequent arrangements that are supplemental to or modify or replace those arrangements. short title this act may be cited as the financial assistance to ukraine act . hl bill financial assistance to ukraine bill

animal welfare bill as brought from the commons contents prohibition of export of livestock for slaughter regulations about enforcement of section section supplementary enforcement regulations procedure etc connected repeals in relation to horses concurrent functions in wales extent, commencement and short title hl bill as brought from the commons a b i l l to prohibit the export of certain livestock from great britain for slaughter. b e it enacted by the king s most excellent majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons, in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows prohibition of export of livestock for slaughter a person may not export relevant livestock from great britain for slaughter. a person who contravenes subsection commits an offence. a person exports relevant livestock from great britain if the person sends, or attempts to send, relevant livestock from great britain to anywhere outside the british islands, the person transports, or attempts to transport, relevant livestock from or through great britain to anywhere outside the british islands, or the person organises, or attempts to organise, the transport of relevant livestock from or through great britain to anywhere outside the british islands. relevant livestock means cattle and other bovine animals, horses and other equine animals, sheep, goats, or pigs or wild boar. a person exports relevant livestock for slaughter if the person exporting the relevant livestock knows, or could reasonably be expected to know, that the relevant livestock is being exported for the purpose of being slaughtered, or for the purpose of being fattened for slaughter. a person who commits an offence under subsection is liable on summary conviction in england and wales, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding the maximum term for summary offences, to a fine or to both; hl bill animal welfare bill on summary conviction in scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding months, to a fine not exceeding level on the standard scale or to both. in subsection , the maximum term for summary offences means if the offence is committed before the time when section of the criminal justice act comes into force, months; if the offence is committed after that time, weeks. regulations about enforcement of section an appropriate national authority may by regulations make provision about the enforcement of section . the provision that may be made by enforcement regulations includes any provision that the appropriate national authority considers appropriate for or in connection with preventing, detecting, investigating or punishing contraventions of section , or other than in relation to scotland, prosecuting offences under section . enforcement regulations may confer a function on a person specified or described in the regulations; make provision about the keeping of records or the provision of information; confer a power of entry ; confer a power of inspection, search, seizure or detention ; authorise, or make provision for the authorisation of, the use of reasonable force in connection with a power mentioned in paragraph or ; confer a power to impose a civil sanction on a person who contravenes section or a provision of the regulations, or obstructs, or fails to assist in, the exercise of a function conferred by the regulations; make provision for the revocation of a person s licence, authorisation or other approval required by or under any enactment for the transport of live animals, where the person contravenes section or a provision of the regulations, or obstructs, or fails to assist in, the exercise of a function conferred by the regulations; create a criminal offence in relation to the contravention of a provision of the regulations, or obstructing, or failing to assist in, the exercise of a function conferred by the regulations; animal welfare bill create a right of appeal; apply, or make provision corresponding to, any provision of, or which may be made under, the animal health act relating to the execution or enforcement of that act, with or without modifications; apply, or make provision corresponding to, any provision that may be made under section of the animal welfare act or section of the animal health and welfare act relating to the enforcement of provision made under the section concerned, with or without modifications. where enforcement regulations confer a power to enter a private dwelling without the consent of the occupier, or with the use of reasonable force, they must provide for the power to be exercisable in england and wales, only on the authority of a warrant issued by a justice of the peace, or in scotland, only on the authority of a warrant issued by a sheriff, summary sheriff or justice of the peace. enforcement regulations may include provision for the imposition of a civil sanction whether or not the conduct in respect of which the sanction is imposed constitutes an offence, the person imposing it is a regulator for the purposes of part of the regulatory enforcement and sanctions act , or the appropriate national authority may make provision for the imposition of sanctions under that part of that act. where enforcement regulations contain provision creating a criminal offence, the provision must have the effect that the offence is triable summarily only, and the offence is punishable only with a fine. section supplementary this section applies for the purposes of section . appropriate national authority , in relation to the power to make enforcement regulations, means the secretary of state; the scottish ministers, so far as provision made by the regulations would be within the legislative competence of the scottish parliament if contained in an act of that parliament; the welsh ministers, so far as provision made by the regulations would be within the legislative competence of senedd cymru if contained in an act of senedd cymru. but the secretary of state may not make enforcement regulations containing provision that could be made by enforcement regulations made by the scottish ministers, or animal welfare bill provision that could be made by enforcement regulations made by the welsh ministers, without the consent of the scottish ministers or the welsh ministers . civil sanction means a sanction of a kind for which provision may be made under part of the regulatory enforcement and sanctions act . enactment means any provision made by or under an act of parliament; an act of the scottish parliament; an act or measure of senedd cymru; assimilated direct legislation. enforcement regulations procedure etc enforcement regulations may make different provision for different purposes or areas; consequential, incidental, supplementary, transitional or saving provision. a power of the secretary of state or the welsh ministers to make enforcement regulations is exercisable by statutory instrument act . the secretary of state may not make a statutory instrument containing enforcement regulations unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each house of parliament. the welsh ministers may not make a statutory instrument containing enforcement regulations unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, senedd cymru. enforcement regulations made by the scottish ministers are subject to the affirmative procedure act . connected repeals in relation to horses in the animal health act omit sections to ; as brought from the commons a b i l l to create offences of dog abduction and cat abduction and to confer a power to make corresponding provision relating to the abduction of other animals commonly authority of the same, as follows dog abduction a person commits the offence of dog abduction if they take a dog so as to remove it from the lawful control of any person, or detain a dog so as to keep it from the lawful control of any person who is entitled to have lawful control of it, and a and the dog are both in england or northern ireland at the time the dog is taken or detained. the offence of dog abduction is not committed if at any time before the taking or detention of the dog the person who took or detained the dog, the person from whose lawful control it was taken or detained, and the dog, all lived together in the same household, a and b had been living together before the dog began to live with them, a and b subsequently ceased to live together, and a took or detained the dog at or after the time when a and b ceased to live together. it is a defence for a person charged with the offence of dog abduction to show that the person had lawful authority or a reasonable excuse for taking or detaining the dog. in relation to england, it is a defence for a person charged with the offence of dog abduction by virtue of subsection to show that the person hl bill pet abduction bill believed that the dog was a stray dog, took all reasonable steps to comply with section of the environmental protection act , and did not detain the dog for more than hours of that act . in dogs order , gave the notice required by article of that order, and took all reasonable steps to comply with arrangements for the collection of the dog made under article of that order. a person is taken to have shown a fact mentioned in subsection , or if sufficient evidence of the fact is adduced to raise an issue with respect to it, and the contrary is not proved beyond reasonable doubt. a person who commits the offence of dog abduction is liable on summary conviction in england and wales, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding the general limit in a magistrates court, or a fine, or both; on summary conviction in northern ireland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding months, or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or both; on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment causing the dog to be taken, and references to a person detaining a dog include the person causing or inducing the dog to remain with the person or anyone else, or causing the dog to be detained. cat as brought from the commons a b i l l to prohibit the sale and advertising of activities abroad which involve low standards of welfare for animals. b e it enacted by the king s most excellent majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons, in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows low welfare animal activities prohibition on sale of low welfare animal activities a person commits an offence if, in a relevant part of the united kingdom, the person sells, or offers or arranges to sell, any right to observe or participate in an activity which involves an animal, takes place outside the united kingdom, and is of a description specified for that part of the united kingdom by regulations made by the appropriate national authority . the appropriate national authority may specify a description of activity in activity regulations only if it considers that an activity of that description involves or is likely to involve keeping the animal in conditions within subsection , or subjecting it to treatment within that subsection. an animal is kept in conditions, or is subject to treatment, within this subsection if keeping the animal in the conditions, or subjecting it to the treatment, in the appropriate national authority s part of the united kingdom would constitute an offence under the appropriate national legislation. prohibition on advertising of low welfare animal activities for the purposes of this section an advertisement is a prohibited advertisement in a relevant part of the united kingdom if the advertisement has the purpose or effect of promoting the observation of, or participation in, an activity which hl bill animals bill involves an animal, takes place outside the united kingdom, and is of a description specified for that part of the united kingdom by activity regulations. a person commits an offence if, in the course of a business, the person publishes in a relevant part of the united kingdom an advertisement that is a prohibited advertisement in that part, or causes such an advertisement to be so published. a person commits an offence if, in the course of a business, the person prints in a relevant part of the united kingdom an advertisement published in that part of the united kingdom that is a prohibited advertisement in that part, or causes such an advertisement to be so printed. a person commits an offence if, in the course of a business, the person distributes in a relevant part of the united kingdom an advertisement published in that part of the united kingdom that is a prohibited advertisement in that part, or causes such an advertisement to be so distributed. a person does not commit an offence under subsection or if the advertisement is contained in a publication which is printed outside a relevant part of the united kingdom, and whose principal market is not, or does not include, a relevant part of the united kingdom or any part of one. a person does not commit an offence under subsection if the distribution is by means of electronic transmission, and the person did not carry on business in a relevant part of the united kingdom at the time of the distribution. a person does not commit an offence under subsection by selling a publication to a member of the public. it is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection or in relation to the printing or distribution of an advertisement in a relevant part of the united kingdom to prove that the person did not know, and had no reason to suspect, that the advertisement would be published in that part. enforcement offences penalties, prosecution and liability a person who commits an offence under this act is liable on summary conviction in england and wales, to a fine; on summary conviction in northern ireland, to a fine not exceeding level on the standard scale. the following do not apply in relation to offences under this act animals bill section of the magistrates courts act ; article of the magistrates courts order . where an offence under this act committed by a body corporate is committed with the consent or connivance of any director, manager, secretary or other similar officer of the body corporate, or any person who was purporting to act in any such capacity, or is attributable to any neglect on the part of any such person, that person as well as the body corporate commits the offence and is liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly. in subsection director , in relation to a body corporate whose affairs are managed by its members, means a member of the body corporate. subsection also applies to a body that is not a body corporate, with the substitution for the reference to a director of the body of a reference in the case of a partnership, to a partner; in the case of an unincorporated body other than a partnership where the body s affairs are managed by its members, to a member of the body; in any other case, to a member of the governing body. enforcement powers of local weights and measures authorities etc a local weights and measures authority in england and the department for the economy in northern ireland may enforce the provisions of this act. for the investigatory powers available for the purpose of enforcing this act, see schedule to the consumer rights act . in paragraph of schedule to the consumer rights act , at the appropriate place insert section of the animals act . the schedule contains provision for the imposition of monetary penalties in respect of offences under this act. general regulations the power to make activity regulations includes power to make different provision for different purposes or for different relevant parts of the united kingdom; consequential, incidental, supplementary, transitional or saving provision. activity regulations made by the secretary of state are to be made by statutory instrument. animals bill the power of the department of agriculture, environment and rural affairs to make activity regulations is exercisable by statutory rule for the purposes of the statutory rules order . the secretary of state may not make a statutory instrument containing activity regulations unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before, and approved by resolution of, each house of parliament. the department of agriculture, environment and rural affairs may not make activity regulations unless a draft of the regulations has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, the northern ireland assembly. interpretation in this act activity regulations means regulations under section ; animal means a vertebrate other than a human; appropriate national authority means in relation to england, the secretary of state; in relation to northern ireland the department of agriculture, environment and rural affairs, or the secretary of state acting with the consent of the department; appropriate national legislation means in relation to england, the animal welfare act ; in relation to northern ireland, the welfare of animals act ; references to offering to sell include making an invitation to treat; relevant part of the united kingdom means england or northern ireland; vertebrate means any animal of the sub phylum vertebrata of the phylum chordata. extent, commencement and short title this act extends to england and wales and northern ireland. this act comes into force at the end of the period of two months beginning with the day on which it is passed. this act may be cited as the animals act . animals bill section schedule monetary penalties enforcement authority in this schedule, enforcement authority means a local weights and measures authority in england, or the department for the economy in northern ireland. imposition of monetary penalties where an enforcement authority is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that a person has committed an offence under section or in the authority s area, the authority may impose a monetary penalty on the person. in this schedule monetary penalty means a requirement to pay the enforcement authority a penalty of an amount determined by the authority. in northern ireland, the amount of the penalty may not exceed an amount equivalent to level on the standard scale. notices and representations where an enforcement authority proposes to impose a monetary penalty on a person the authority must give the person a notice of what is proposed . an initial penalty notice must offer the person the opportunity to avoid liability in relation as brought from the commons a b i l l to make provision to prevent the theft and re sale of equipment and tools used by tradespeople and agricultural and other businesses; and for connected purposes. b e it enacted by the king s most excellent majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons, in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows requirements for sale of equipment the secretary of state may by regulations make provision to restrict the sale of specified equipment where a specified requirement is not met. regulations under subsection may specify equipment of a kind falling within the following descriptions mechanically propelled vehicles that are designed or adapted primarily for use other than on a road, have an engine capacity of at least cubic centimeters or two kilowatts, and travel on more than two wheels or on tracks; other equipment designed or adapted primarily for use in agricultural or commercial activities. regulations under subsection may specify a requirement of a kind falling within the following descriptions a requirement that the equipment is fitted with a device designed, or adapted, to be fitted for the purposes of preventing the equipment from being driven or otherwise put in motion; a requirement that the equipment is marked with a unique identifier, and a visible indication that it is marked with a unique identifier. regulations under subsection may not restrict the sale of equipment if the sale is solely for the purposes of onward sale by the buyer, or the equipment has previously been used for the purpose for which it was primarily designed or adapted. in this act hl bill equipment theft bill equipment includes a vehicle; equipment is not used for the purpose for which it was primarily designed or adapted solely by virtue of being used in order to demonstrate its features to a potential buyer of the equipment or other equipment of the same or a similar kind, or in preparation for such a demonstration. record keeping the secretary of state may by regulations provide that a person selling equipment of a kind falling within a description in section must record specified information in connection with the sale. the information may include, for example a name, address or telephone number, or other contact details, of the buyer, the make, model or colour of the equipment, if the equipment is marked with a unique identifier of a kind specified in regulations under section details of that unique identifier, and the method or location of the marking, and the date on which the contract of sale was entered into. regulations under subsection may make provision about when the information must be recorded; for how long the information must be kept; the form in which the information must be kept . regulations under subsection may not require a person selling equipment to record information if the sale is solely for the purposes of onward sale by the buyer, or the equipment has previously been used for the purpose for which it was primarily designed or adapted. enforcement a person commits an offence if the person sells equipment in breach of regulations under section , or fails to record or keep information in accordance with regulations under section . a person that commits an offence under subsection is liable on summary conviction to a fine. an enforcement authority may enforce regulations under section or in their area. equipment theft bill for the powers available to an enforcement authority for the purposes of enforcing regulations under section or , see schedule to the consumer rights act . enforcement authority means a local weights and measures authority, or a district council that is not a local weights and measures authority. in paragraph of schedule to the consumer rights act , at the end insert section of the equipment theft act . regulations general a power to make regulations under any provision of this act includes power to make consequential, supplementary, transitional or saving provision; different provision for different purposes. regulations under this act are to be made by statutory instrument. a statutory instrument containing regulations under this act may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before and approved by a resolution of each house of parliament. extent, commencement and short title this act extends to england and wales. this act comes into force at the end of the period of six months beginning with the day on which this act is passed. this act may be cited as the equipment theft act . equipment theft bill
